s.text: Similar results are obtained using the genomic DNA-based assay, although these results cannot be interpreted in a C H -specific manner (data not shown).

Because these are true clonal expansions (ie increased numbers of B cells per specific clone), it is likely that the antigenic exposures are chronic and therefore are increasing the numbers of memory B cells reactive with these determinants.
cDNA (2?l) was amplified using a sense V H family-specific FR1 primer in conjunction with the appropriate antisense C H primer.

The present study was designed to analyze further the level of clonal diversity in rheumatoid arthritis B cells by using the length of the third complementarity determining region (CDR3) of the rearranged heavy (H) chain variable region (V) gene as a marker (herein referred to as HCDR3).

Because these are true clonal expansions (ie increased numbers of B cells per specific clone), it is likely that the antigenic exposures are chronic and therefore are increasing the numbers of memory B cells reactive with these determinants.

This could be a reflection of the numbers of V H genes present in the V H family being analyzed (it is more likely to see a non-Gaussian distribution in families with small numbers of individual genes) or of the state of activation of a specific clone (because activated B cells contain much higher levels of V gene messenger RNA than resting B cells).

During normal B cell development, the processes of gene segment recombination and coding end processing yield nucleotide HCDR3 lengths that are characteristic and virtually invariant for an individual B-cell clone.
It is likely that the B cells that mature in these 'pseudogerminal centers' and those that we have identified in the present studies are responding to specific (auto)antigens.
It is likely that the B cells that mature in these 'pseudogerminal centers' and those that we have identified in the present studies are responding to specific (auto)antigens.
It is likely that the B cells that mature in these 'pseudogerminal centers' and those that we have identified in the present studies are responding to specific (auto)antigens.
In contrast to the extensive studies of the clonal distribution of T cells in rheumatoid arthritis, much less is known about the level of B-cell diversity in this disease.
An even more striking level of B-cell clonal dominance and expansion was seen when the genomic DNA-based assay was used to analyze B cells from the synovial fluid or synovial tissue (Figs 2and 3).

One microgram of RNA was reverse transcribed to complementary (c)DNA using 200U Moloney murine leukemia virua (M-MLV) reverse transcriptase (GIBCO BRL Life Technologies, Grand Island, NY, USA), 1U RNAse inhibitor (5 Prime 3 Prime, Boulder, CO, USA) and 20 pmol oligo dT primer in a total volume of 20 ?l.

One microgram of RNA was reverse transcribed to complementary (c)DNA using 200U Moloney murine leukemia virua (M-MLV) reverse transcriptase (GIBCO BRL Life Technologies, Grand Island, NY, USA), 1U RNAse inhibitor (5 Prime 3 Prime, Boulder, CO, USA) and 20 pmol oligo dT primer in a total volume of 20 ?l.
Because DNA levels are not appreciably altered by cellular activation, however, the use of genomic DNA as well as cDNA from the same sample of B cells helps to distinguish these two processes.
For example, clonal amplifications of CD8 +CD57 +T cells are frequently found in the T-cell repertoire of rheumatoid arthritis patients [ 4].

Furthermore, because it is unlikely that each joint would harbor a different foreign antigen, these B cells are most likely reacting with autoantigens generated locally, possibly by local tissue breakdown.
Figures 2and 3illustrate data that suggest that there are expanded clones that are blood restricted, joint restricted, or are common to both compartments.
The genomic DNA-based assays in both patients indicated that clonal expansions are common in the blood of rheumatoid arthritis patients.

This indicates that there are no dominant HCDR3 lengths that skew the Gaussian distribution, and therefore that there are no significant clonal expansions among the B cells that express most of these V H -C H combinations.

In this patient, the DNA-based assay provided examples of clonal expansions that were present in only one joint (eg the V H 3-J H and V H 5-J H combinations in Figure 4), and the companion cDNA-based assays indicated that in some instances these expansions were either activated or resting.
